entry.title: iniBuilds Releases Dallas Fort Worth International Airport for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iniBuilds has just released its version of Dallas Fort Worth International Airport (KDFW) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024. This airport serves the Dallas‚ÄìFort Worth‚ÄìArlington metropolitan area and was the world‚Äôs fourth-busiest airport by passenger traffic last year, welcoming an impressive 85.6 million passengers. The airport began commercial operations in 1974 under the name Dallas/Fort Worth Regional Airport. It was renamed Dallas/Fort Worth International in 1985. Initially, the airport had just four terminals, but it has since expanded to five, with plans for a sixth terminal underway. With seven runways, the airport accommodates nearly 90 million passengers each year. It serves a variety of airlines and is a hub for American Airlines, Ameriflight, Southern Airways Express, and UPS Airlines, while also serving as a base of operations for Frontier Airlines and Spirit Airlines. These airlines, along with many others, offer destinations worldwide. iniBuilds has included a comprehensive set of features in the scenery package. It features highly detailed models of all airport buildings, objects, and surrounding areas, as well as a full HD ground polygon. The airport layout is up-to-date, and it includes high-definition jetways and dynamic airport lighting. Additionally, the package contains a fully modelled and animated Skylink Air Train system, among a variety of other features. The newly released Dallas Fort Worth International Airport is now available from iniBuilds for $27.57. ‚Äç For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! ‚Äç If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: X-Codr Designs Announces Airport Enhancement Package 2.0 for X-Plane
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. X-Codr has recently announced a substantial update to their Airport Enhancement Package add-on for X-Plane, bringing procedurally generated life to over 36,000 airports around the globe. While the original AEP focused on replacing key assets (ground textures, common buildings, and service vehicles), AEP 2.0 aims to add to airports, not just replace assets around them. After months of development and tinkering, the developer has managed to create a program that reads and understands the global airports, procedurally generating overlays that greatly enhance the experience with tire skids on taxi routes, runways, and service roads, additional clutter at gates and near buildings, grunge, oil leaks, rust, and random ramp clutter, yielding a more lifelike experience around every airport in the simulator. While the procedural generation is the new star of the show, it doesn‚Äôt mean AEP no longer replaces assets, with over a thousand custom assets in total, including new pavement textures, service vehicles, new cars, all of the legacy hangars (and new ones), and various clutter objects. There are a couple of things that are still being worked on before release, such as more baggage cart variants, old long metal hangars, cargo area clutter, stability testing for a new feature yet to be announced, and beta testing. They also use this opportunity to seek people willing to help stress-test the new product and aid in shaping the final release through their contact page or Discord. Furthermore, the developer has also mentioned that it will be a free upgrade for AEP 1.0 owners. If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! ‚Äç

entry.title: FSDG Releases Cape Verde Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. FSDG has recently released their rendition of Am√≠lcar Cabral International Airport (GVAC) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, serving Espargos, Sal, in Cape Verde, with an average of 1.2 million passengers per year. It was built in 1939 by the Italians as a pit stop for flights from Europe to South America, though their involvement ended quickly due to World War 2. It wasn‚Äôt until the end of the conflict that Portugal purchased it from Italy and began its completion, becoming fully operational by 1949. For a bit more than a decade, between 1963 and 1975, the Portuguese Air Force operated at the airport, providing support to military air connections between Portugal and its African provinces and serving as an operational base for patrol aircraft occasionally deployed there. To this day, it‚Äôs still an important stopover for international flights and one of the most common ETOPS destinations, in case any flight encounters a failure mid-crossing the ocean. It‚Äôs a hub for Cabo Verde Airlines, and served by AlbaStar, Air Senegal, Binter Canarias, Bulgaria Air, Corendon, easyJet, Edelweiss, Enter Air, Luxair, Neos, Royal Air Maroc, Smartwings, Sunclass, TAP Air Portugal, Transavia, TUI Airways, TUI fly Belgium, TUI fly Deutschland, TUI fly Netherlands, TUI fly Nordic, and Vueling. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with an up-to-date ground layout, detailed 3D models, a custom interior for the passenger terminal, realistic night lighting, performance-friendly optimization, and more. ‚Äã It‚Äôs available on SimMarket for roughly $20, requiring at least 60.59 MB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: Gaya Simulations Announces Corfu International Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Gaya Simulations has recently announced their return to consumer-facing development with a Corfu International Airport (LGKR) rendition for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, serving Corfu, Greece, with an average of 4.3 million passengers per year. ‚Äã It was founded in 1937 and was taken over by the Axis forces shortly after, serving as a base for transport and fighter aircraft. During most of its early life, the runway was only 600 meters long. ‚Äã It wasn‚Äôt until 1949 that Corfu would get its first runway expansion, adding 200 meters in total length, and then nearly doubling a few years later to accommodate larger aircraft. ‚Äã The first passenger terminal was built in 1962, and its International debut happened three years later. ‚Äã With its newly granted international status and an ever-rising yearly passenger count, a new terminal was built between 1968 and 1972. ‚Äã As of 10 years ago, Corfu International was privatized and acquired by a joint venture between Fraport and the Copelouzos Group. The deal will be valid for 40 years as of 2017. ‚Äã It‚Äôs a focus city for Aegean Airlines and Ryanair. Air France, Air Serbia, Arkia, Austrian Airlines, Brussels Airlines, easyJet, Edelweiss Air, Eurowings, ITA Airways, Jet2.com, Luxair, Neos, Norwegian Air Shuttle, Scandinavian Airlines, Sky Express, Smartwings, Swiss, Transavia, TUI, Volotea, and Wizz Air also serve it. ‚Äã The developers promise an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground textures, high-quality 3d models, and up-to-date ground layout, custom night lighting, custom ground service equipment, and more. ‚Äã There‚Äôs no information regarding pricing or the release date yet, but Threshold will keep you informed. Furthermore, the developers have refined the Flight Management System with improved fuel planning, vertical navigation, and route editing. The holding pattern logic has also been improved. Vertical and lateral navigation were tweaked to ensure better waypoint handling, corrected constraint formatting, refined DIR TO logic, enhanced airway and manual waypoint validation, and more. The navigation tweaks brought on by this update will lay the groundwork for the implementation of FLS (Flight Management Landing System), which is already in active development. ‚Äç The passenger cabin has been entirely reworked, with high-resolution textures, per-variant accuracy, animated window blinds, customized lighting environments, and a fully functional cabin signage system. entry.title: PhotoRico Releases Mu√±oz Mar√≠n International Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. PhotoRico has recently released their rendition of Mu√±oz Mar√≠n International Airport (TJSJ) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, serving San Juan, Puerto Rico, with an average of 13.4 million passengers per year. Planning for the airport‚Äôs construction began in 1945, when the government recognized they‚Äôd need a newer, larger airport to keep up with the air traffic demands of the following decades, since the region's main airport had a very short runway and could not be expanded further. The project received approval in 1946; work began in 1947, and by 1949, they had completed the first phase, which involved cleaning, filling, leveling, and draining the soil. By the latter half of that year, they were already paving the runways and taxiways. The inauguration only took place in 1955, six years later, with a six-story passenger terminal, a control tower, a 2,400-meter-long runway, and basic aeroportuary infrastructure. ‚Äã The 1960s brought further expansion, including lengthening the runway for jets and the addition of a second runway (which was only completed in the 1970s). ‚Äã In the late 1980s, a $137 million investment was announced to expand the passenger terminal and make multiple improvements to the airport, which were carried out between the 90s and early 2000s. ‚Äã It was followed by another terminal expansion in the early 2000s, making Terminal B slightly larger and remodeling the hotel, among other minor things. In the 2010s, despite the significant drawbacks of the 2008 crisis (leading, for example, to American Airlines greatly reducing its presence), the airport underwent further work, including a new passenger terminal, new pavement, new lighting systems, press conference rooms, and more. ‚Äã It‚Äôs a hub for M&N Aviation and Tradewind Aviation, and a focus city for JetBlue. Air Canada Rouge, Air Transat, American Airlines, Arajet, Avelo Airlines, Avianca, Cape Air, Contour Airlines, Copa Airlines, Delta Airlines, Frontier Airlines, Iberia, Southwest Airlines, Spirit, Sun Country Airlines, United Airlines, and WestJet also serve it. ‚Äã The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with fully detailed terminals, an up-to-date ground layout, custom jetways, custom taxi lights, performance-friendly optimization, and custom weathering. ‚Äã It‚Äôs available on OrbxDirect (2020/2024) for roughly $22.38, requiring at least 1.60 GB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: Orbx Releases Nordheimer Creek Ranch for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Orbx has recently released their rendition of Nordheimer Creek Ranch (CA107) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, a tricky airstrip tucked into a steep, narrow mountain valley in California. Located in the Six Rivers National Forest (Orleans, California), the Nordheimer Ranch Airfield is one of the most challenging airstrips in the United States, with a punishingly short runway and difficult terrain, with no margin for error. The area is known for its high-altitude lakes, dense forests, and diverse wildlife, attracting tourists from all over. Furthermore, its rich past continues to attract attention to this day, be it the remnants of old mining operations and the ancient fruit trees left by homesteaders centuries ago. It‚Äôs also famously known for world-class kayaking and rafting, with the nearby Nordheimer Campground being a very popular base for rafters. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airstrip, with high-fidelity visuals, PBR texturing, advanced collision modeling for out-of-cockpit exploration, and much more. ‚ÄãIt‚Äôs available on OrbxDirect for roughly $8.53, requiring at least 485.70 MB of free hard disk space to install.
